title.rendered: Slow-Speed Chase in L.A. Ends in Bizarre Way

content.rendered:
Los Angeles News | FOX 11 LA KTTV

A driver suspected of DUI was pulled over but then took off, leading police on an hour-long slow-speed chase down a main drag in the San Fernando Valley of Los Angeles Friday.

The chase ended when a man who witnesses at the scene described as homeless stepped into traffic and blocked the car with his body, side-stepping to stay in front of it as the driver tried to move around him.
At that point, the driver got out and the bystander who stopped him walked up to him and grabbed his collar. Police moved in and arrested both of them.

Police said they detained the bystander for questioning and he was being held for a possible parole violation.

Via Kiro TV

title.rendered: Engine Ejects from Lamborghini Crash

content.rendered: During a race a few years back someone captured footage of this Lamborghini crashing into a wall. While many thought that the driver was ejected from the car during the wreck it was actually the entire engine that shot across the road. These supercars are so potentially explosive and flammable that they all have engines designed to separate from the vehicle on impact to minimize the danger of it exploding near the driver.

title.rendered: Jalopnik Test Drives New Camaro and Crashes, Then Gets Tossed From GM

content.rendered:
Patrick George is a writer for Jalopnik who recently had a pretty bad time in a Camaro. Not any Camaro, the brand new 2016 Camaro. GM invited him and other journalists out to the Belle Island track in Detroit to see their new Camaro and each got to drive a mule (a version of the car with a weird white and black camo paint cover) for a press event. While following one car behind the lead Patrick took the wrong line going into a turn and wound up hitting the wall. GM wasn’t all that fond of Jalopnik since they leaked their C7 Corvette in the first place so they didn’t take too kindly to Patrick for the wreck and they requested he leave the facility.

Sorry Patrick, that’s a legitimate bummer!

GM wasn't all that fond of Jalopnik since they leaked their C7 Corvette in the first place so they didn't take too kindly to Patrick for the wreck and they requested he leave the facility.

This Civic must have forgotten that lesson. He pulls out in front of this semi who has no time to stop so he lays on the horn and tries to dodge it but simply can’t.

The car behind him, admittedly driving a bit more recklessly than is likely advised, has to swerve to avoid the scooter and winds up causing a fairly large accident. The worst is when the scooter notices what he’s done and just leaves as if none of it is his fault!

title.rendered: A Man Outbid the Son of a Fallen Sheriff Over His Old Police Car, Then Gifts Him the Car!

content.rendered: Here’s a heart warming story to brighten your day. Five years ago this guy’s father was a Sheriff who tragically died in the line of duty. The police department eventually put his old Charger up for auction. The Sheriff’s son had saved up money to try and purchase his late father’s car as a keepsake. However he was out bid at the last moment and couldn’t go any higher. It’s then that the man who outbid him decided to help the young man out and see his father’s car returned to family it belongs in!

title.rendered: Photographing NASCAR

content.rendered: For those that have never been to a live race, especially a NASCAR race, have no idea just how FAST drivers are racing around the track. You simply can’t conceptualize the sheer speed by watching it on television or online. You have to be right up next to the track to catch the blur speed past you and the wind nearly knock you down. Until you can see it for yourself watch this video of a photographer posted up just barely off the track to get a sense of just how quickly NASCAR races really run.

title.rendered: Barn Find 1962 Impala SS Convertible in Spokane, Washington

content.rendered:
Barn finds have a unique appeal to them. They’re basically the epitome of buried treasure to classic car lovers. Nick and Evan over at Classic Nation have stumbled upon their own amazing barn find. They came across this beautiful 1962 Impala SS Convertible. It’s been left all alone and neglected for over 30 years!

by Nick from Classic Nation

For us gear heads, few things in life are more exciting than the idea of stumbling upon our very own muscle car barn find. It doesn’t matter if you are a Ford, Chevy, or Mopar guy, we all dream about finding that classic car, forgotten by time and covered with dust, and the thought of what we would do to it if were were able to seal the deal and bring it back home. The reality is that these opportunities are quickly disappearing, so if any of the real die-hards or car nuts do happen to find a barn find classic car, chances are they wont let it slip out of their hands.

For the fans of the full size Chevy’s, the Impala holds a special place in their hearts. The unique three taillight design combined with long swooping lines make almost every early 60’s Impala distinctly coveted. Of the early 60’s Impalas, one of the most popular would (arguably) be the 1962, which is a tasteful blend of a a modernized ’61, with classic lines often favored among the pre ’64 X-Frame versions.

Imagine, then, you are an Impala lover and you stumble upon a barn find 1962 Impala that has been forgotten and neglected for 30+ years. What could be better than that? Well, imagine that Impala was a convertible. Crazy, right? It doesn’t get any better than that… except if that 1962 Impala convertible barn find turns out to be a true SS. Well, that dream was a reality for me, and I’m the proud new owner of a barn find 1962 Impala Super Sport Convertible.

Sure it need a lot of things and some of the panels aren’t original, but that’s part of the fun.

After running the numbers, I found out that this car was a Los Angeles built car, originally Nissau Blue exterior with a blue interior, and fitted with an ivory convertible top. Without an engine and transmission present, its difficult to identify exactly what engine and tranny combo was originally fitted, but a little research showed that the 3/8 fuel line (likely not changed) and dual exhaust, and absence of a ballast resistor on the cowl pointed to the car being equipped with a 327, possibly the 300hp version, and due to process of elimination, not a 283, or the rare and cool 409 425hp (darn).

One of the things that makes this car really cool is that fact that an Ivory top (RPO 470B) “wasn’t available” on a Nissau blue car. Only white, blue and black tops were available with convertibles. That means, there’s a good chance this car was a special order, as the cowl tag shows the ivory top, and there is a decaying ivory top on the car. Not only is this really rare, but it’s actually a really great looking combo!

The car was also equipped with power brakes and power steering, nice touches for a ’62.

So what are my plans after getting it home? I’ll get it cleaned up, then… I’m not sure. Probably build it into a 1962 Impala SS convertible dream car! Stay tuned!

Needless to say, they have a lot of work ahead of them, but they are more than capable of restoring this beauty to its former glory! Check out some of the other photos of their find below.

So what’s this car going to look like when I’m finished? Probably, really similar to the day it rolled off the assembly line. Same color. Same top. A lot like this. (This one has a white top and mine will have the correct ivory top).

Be sure to visit Classic Nation for updates on their whole restoration project. Remember to submit your stories to alt_driver to be featured.

title.rendered: Incredible Wrecker Skills!

content.rendered:
This tow truck driver skillfully answered the scene of a pretty gnarly accident. The Charger driver suffered a seizure behind the wheel and wound up careening over the cub, crushing the front end of the Honda Accord and rolling the Civic on its side. No one was hurt but it all needed to be cleaned up.

The wrecker uses a healthy amount of know how and a decent knowledge of physics to wrest the Charger free with as little additional damage to the other cars as possible.

title.rendered: Motorcyclist Tries to Cut Through Stalled Traffic, Gets Pissed When it Doesn’t Work Out

content.rendered:
In this video from JukinVideo, this motorcyclist is undeniably aggravated at other drivers who lack the foresight to not block intersections when traffic is heavy and lights change. He decides to cut through some cars blocking the way when one driver nudges forward at the perfectly wrong moment. He taps the rider and causes him to lay his bike down.

Now, the biker is understandably angry but should he have avoided trying that move in the first place?

Take a look at this video from Jalopnik showcasing some of the larger custom vehicles they engineered for the film!

title.rendered: Did the Police Pull Over the Wrong Challenger For Speeding?

content.rendered:
Dodge Challenger rockets past cop, but does the cop run down the right one? We then see the police in hot pursuit. Just a few moments down the road the camera picks up the police having pulled over a Challenger, presumably the same one the driver spotted earlier. However when the driver comes up upon the pulled over vehicle it appears to be an entirely different Challenger. It’s got an entirely different package with different stripes, chrome additions and wheels.

The story goes that the driver contacted the police who weren’t interested in the dash footage. However after posting the video to some Challenger forums the web has come through and the police are now suddenly interested in what the cam picked up.

Check out more on the story over at Japlonik.

title.rendered: German Police Try to Tackle the Nurburgring

Germany is not the United Arab Emirates, by which we mean they don’t have a city like Dubai whose police force rides around in Bugattis. Instead they have some sort of…a tactical authority station wagon?
At any rate, here’s footage of some German officers trying to take their car around the ‘ring. While it’s not a full lap, just seeing their difficulty with this particular set of curves shows how hard a time they’d have chasing down anything that knows how to run the ring.

However, as you’ll see in his video review he finds out he couldn’t have been more wrong in his assumptions.

title.rendered: This Lamborghini Huracan Pretty Much Jumps to Lightspeed

content.rendered:
Check out this video featuring former Formula One driver Nicolas Kiesa behind the wheel of a Lamborghini Huracan laying it down in the city of Roskilde, Copenhagen. He wails on this V10 and hit speeds up to 171 MPH on this course that’s not designed for insanely high speeds. This makes everything appear tiny and disappear in the blink on an eye…pretty much like driving at light speed!

The first video is the raw footage but if you prefer more stabilized footage than watch the second clip!

title.rendered: The AMC AMX – An Overlooked Classic

content.rendered:
When it comes to the classic American car scene everybody spends their time fawning over old Mustangs, GTOs, Bel-Airs, etc. People often overlook one classic in particular that deserves plenty of attention on its own. This free episode of /Driven features one particularly cherry 1969 AMC AMX.
They’re a little quirky as vintage cars go and was only offered for around 3 years but take a look at this episode and see why the AMX deserves a sport in every car aficionado’s heart.

It’s powered by a V12 turbo engine that produces 700 HP and can hoof it from 0 to 60 MPH in 4.4 seconds, topping out at 218 MPH. There may only be the one in the world but you’re able to see it in action right here!

title.rendered: Idiot Helps Give BMW Drivers a Bad Name

content.rendered: When you watch the above video of an inconsiderate moron spinning donuts in the middle of a busy intersection in an E36 3-Series you’ll probably jump to a lot of conclusions about the driver. You’ll probably think that they’re spoiled douchebags who didn’t pay for that car and don’t care about any damage or harm their reckless behavior might cost anyone. And you’ll probably think that all BMW drivers are just like him. Which, while easy to believe, is totally wrong.

content.rendered: Auto mechanic Rick Sullivan took 6 months and $6,000 along with a boat load of spare parts to create this unique conversion. It’s a ’91 Ford Ranger with a ’95 F-150 body placed on top of it. Rick got the idea after driving past an overturned truck on the side of the road and wanted to replicate it as an actual working truck.

title.rendered: 3-D Printed Electric Shelby Cobra Replica

content.rendered: The U.S. Department of Energy made a lot of heads turn at this year’s Detroit Auto Show back in January when they showed off their 3-D printed electric car. While they touted that it was a Shelby Cobra “replica” it’s really just an inspired design. With everything getting the 3-D printing treatment these days it’s incredible to see what people are capable to assembling!

title.rendered: Nitrogen vs. Air in Tires

content.rendered: Formula 1 cars drive around on tires filled with Nitrogen instead of regular Air. They do this because Nitrogen filled tires tend to maintain their held pressure for longer while also removing any and all water vapor inside the tire that might sneak in with regular Air. Here the guys at Fifth Gear do a little testing to see which type of tire works better in every day conditions.

title.rendered: World Cup Star Annihilates GT-R in Huge Wreck

content.rendered: This is video of Russia’s soccer star Andrey Yeshchenko proving that he’s far better at playing soccer than driving. Luckily, the star player walked away from the crash without any serious injuries. He was supposedly traveling around 105 MPH when he met the wrong side of that pole.

title.rendered: Idiot BMW X5 Driver Brake Checks a 40 Ton Truck

content.rendered:
From that land that features the very best of dash cam footage, Russia, comes this video where a BMW driver takes personal offense towards a large truck that apparently cut him off. The BMW driver then decides, like a genius, he’s going to get in front of said truck and teach him a lesson with a series of increasingly poor brake checks.
Learn from this man.
Do no repeat his mistakes.
